comments.text:
+cre8ivartist 
"A free market is a market not regulated by the government"

Not just regulation, but government intervention in general. I don't fully 
advocate a free market because it probably isn't realistic to achieve 
(since nobody initiates force in a free market, which might not be 
realistic), but this whole issue with private prisons and law enforcement 
corruption is an issue because of government intervention (since the 
"private" prison industry is funded the government). If the government 
didn't set up a private prison industry, this wouldn't be a problem. 

If you didn't understand, what I'm trying to say is that if government 
doesn't have too much power to interfere with the market, things like this 
would never happen.

rest of us, we'd call them cows. It would be confusing.

top_comment.text:
The incarceration of children is a *race issue*. But before you go off on 
accusing me of tossing out a race card, here is why. The criminal justice 
system is allowed to benefit the corporate prison system because the 
majority of people, (Whites), are not affected at a rate that minorities 
are. If White kids were incarcerated at the rate of Black kids, Whites 
would put an end to the current policies that Blacks are subjected to. Most 
kids are incarcerated for drugs. Yet we know that Whites use drugs at a 
rate that is proportional to their numbers in society... just like other 
races.﻿
top_comment.author: Commodoor64

comments.text:
+Chompjil
Until the issue of the over-incarceration of people for non-violent crimes 
is felt by the majority of the people, things will not change. Yes, we're 
all people, but when the majority (Whites) are excluded from the process 
there is no impetus for change. BTW, I'm White.
comments.author: Commodoor64

comments.text:
Locking up the wrong/innocent people is a bad thing. There are simply no 
facts to support that the 'for profit' jail system is beneficial to 
society. Only a benefit for the person seeing the profit. Im very surprised 
at your comment, its almost as if you didn't even watch the video.
comments.author: rustynuggets

comments.text:
Of course some people need to be locked up to protect society but 
oftentimes when you lock up nonviolent offenders en masse like this it 
hurts society.  The money wasted to imprison these people is outrageous.  

Average cost for 1 juveniles alone in one year is between $35,000 to 
$64,000. For that money, you could hire a social workers.  Think of how 
many kids he/she could help.  I'd rather that money be spent to keep them 
from committing crimes in the first place.  

Besides, think of the harm caused by the escalation of criminal activities 
taught in jails and prisons.  By and large, juvenile detention doesn't save 
children, it winds up condemning them to a life of crime and it condemns 
society to a never-ending cycle of victimization.
comments.author: Darisha Sims

comments.text:
I think you are missing the point.  This judge was basically paid to put

comments.author: Skikx

comments.text:
+Skikx That is completely wrong. Locks work for 2 reasons. 1. Social 
instruction. 2. Fear of prison. If it weren't for both we would need better 
locks. If it was JUST 1 or 2 the crime would still happen. Those that 
ignore #1 are the ones that don't fear #2. The FEAR (of social unacceptance 
or the punishment) is what keeps honest people honest.
comments.author: Erichev

comments.text:
Overwhelming scientific studies say your stance is flawed. So overwhelming, 
you might as well argue that Elvis is still alive while you're at it

comments.text:

If you want to keep people from doing bad things, you must teach them why 
it is a bad thing to do in the first place.
